items.synopsis: Gautam Adani won the tender to transform one of the world's largest slums into a thriving, modern metropolis. But those in Dharavi fear the development could push them out and turn it into a playground for the rich.

title.children: India's rich and famous live on the edge of a Mumbai slum. Now the land has become highly coveted

image.altText: A woman cries in front of a car.

items.synopsis: The woman who hosted the lunch that police believe resulted in three people dying from mushroom poisoning has spoken of her anguish at the deaths and denied doing anything wrong.

title.children: The woman who cooked a fatal meal for three people in Victoria's east says she's 'devastated' by the deaths

image.altText: Bec Nicoll and Sarah Thomson crouch with their two dogs, on the ground of their wrecked house.

items.synopsis: Australians are facing a "broken" insurance system as the risk of bushfires, floods and cyclones increases with climate change, a new report out today says.

title.children: Bec and Sarah didn't want to repair a property that could just flood again. Turns out, their insurance claim wasn't that simple

image.altText: People silhouetted against a white and blue KPMG logo.

items.synopsis: Newly compiled data reveals Defence has spent nearly $4 billion on large consulting firms over the past decade, more than all other Australian government departments combined.

title.children: 'Something's rotten': New analysis reveals $4 billion Defence department spend on consultancy firms

image.altText: A green sign on a construction site saying 'a head start to a hands-on career'

items.synopsis: It's been revealed the SA government is spending $1.2 million of funding allocated for public schools on an advertising campaign spruiking five technical colleges it promised to build if elected, sparking criticism from teachers and the opposition.

title.children: Education boss reveals department using Gonski funding to spruik new technical colleges

image.altText: A woman in a winter coat and glasses.

items.synopsis: A court has heard that the woman accused of murdering her father by injecting him with her own insulin was last seen at his house hours before he was found unconscious.

title.children: 'Form of tranquilliser' found in the system of 94yo allegedly murdered by his daughter, court hears

image.altText: A composite image of Christopher Pyne and Joe Hockey

items.synopsis: In Australia there has long been disquiet about the revolving door between high political office and big business. Look at the defence industry, for example, writes Linton Besser.

title.children: A new generation of former MPs has turned to big business

items.synopsis: In the 1967 referendum on Indigenous rights, the NSW electorate of Cowper recorded one of the highest "no" votes. Now, Gumbaynggirr elders are reflecting on past lessons as they prepare for the second Indigenous referendum in their lifetime.

title.children: 'Feels like hatred': Meet the town that voted 'no' in the last Indigenous referendum

items.synopsis: Today's latest news, as it happens.

title.children: Judge dismisses Donald Trump's defamation claim against E. Jean Carroll — The latest news with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australian police arrested almost 160 people as part of a national crackdown on outlaw motorcycle gangs, which ran for a week and ended on Sunday. AAP reports that the country-wide operation, dubbed Taskforce Morpheus, led to almost 700 charges and seized 43 firearms, along with more than 20 other weapons, 11 vehicles and hundreds of thousands of dollars in cash. Officers also seized various quantities of different drugs during more than 70 raids across the country. "The success of this week of action should serve as a fresh warning to OMCG [outlaw motorcycle gang] members in Australia and those seeking to hideout offshore," national Taskforce Morpheus chair Detective Superintendent Anthony Conway says. "There is nowhere to run, and there is nowhere to hide."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Latest bikie crackdown leads to almost 700 charges

props.alt: The backs of a large number of bikies on motorcycles, as they drive away

children.content: (AAP File)
Australian police arrested almost 160 people as part of a national crackdown on outlaw motorcycle gangs, which ran for a week and ended on Sunday.
AAP reports that the country-wide operation, dubbed Taskforce Morpheus, led to
almost 700 charges and seized 43 firearms, along with more than 20 other weapons, 11 vehicles and hundreds of thousands of dollars in cash
Officers also seized various quantities of different drugs during more than 70 raids across the country.

"The success of this week of action should serve as a fresh warning to OMCG [outlaw motorcycle gang] members in Australia and those seeking to hideout offshore," national Taskforce Morpheus chair Detective Superintendent Anthony Conway says.
"There is nowhere to run, and there is nowhere to hide."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: By Brad Ryan in Washington DC There’s been a small development in Donald Trump's court case here in Washington DC. If you were following the news last week, you'd know Trump was indicted on conspiracy charges related to efforts to overturn the 2020 election result. After last week's court appearance, Trump posted on his Truth Social platform: "IF YOU GO AFTER ME, I'M COMING AFTER YOU!" That threatening post prompted prosecutors to respond with a late-night court application to have the former president prevented from going too far with his social posts. In particular, prosecutors raised concerns Trump could publicly reveal confidential material that they will need to give his legal team as part of the court process. They asked the court to issue a "protective order" that would restrict any sharing of that material to a select group of people with a direct stake in the case. A short time ago, Trump's legal team formally responded to the prosecution's request, asking the court to narrow the proposed order "to shield only genuinely sensitive materials from public view". It says the prosecutors' request represents an attempt by the government to limit Trump's First Amendment free speech rights. "Worse, it does this against this administration's primary political opponent, during an election season in which the administration, prominent party members, and media allies have campaigned on the indictment," the response lodged with the court says. The court is yet to decide on the application.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Prosecutors are attempting to limit Trump's posting about his indictment

children.content: By Brad Ryan in Washington DC
There’s been a small development in Donald Trump's court case here in Washington DC.
If you were following the news last week, you'd know Trump was indicted on conspiracy charges related to efforts to overturn the 2020 election result.
After last week's court appearance, Trump posted on his Truth Social platform: "IF YOU GO AFTER ME, I'M COMING AFTER YOU!"
That threatening post prompted prosecutors to respond with a late-night court application
to have the former president prevented from going too far with his social posts.

props.alt: Donald Trump speaking at a lecturn in a suit and tie

children.content: (AP: Artie Walker Jr.)
In particular,
prosecutors raised concerns Trump could publicly reveal confidential material
that they will need to give his legal team as part of the court process.
They asked the court to issue a "protective order" that would restrict any sharing of that material to a select group of people with a direct stake in the case.
A short time ago, Trump's legal team formally responded to the prosecution's request, asking the court to
narrow the proposed order
"to shield only genuinely sensitive materials from public view".
It says the prosecutors' request represents an attempt by the government to limit Trump's First Amendment free speech rights.

"Worse, it does this against this administration's primary political opponent, during an election season in which the administration, prominent party members, and media allies have campaigned on the indictment," the response lodged with the court says.
The court is yet to decide on the application.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A federal judge in the US has tossed out former president Donald Trump's countersuit against writer E. Jean Carroll, who won a $US5 million ($7.6 million) sex abuse lawsuit against him in May. The judge ruled that Trump can't claim Carroll defamed him by continuing to say she was not only sexually abused but raped. Trump attorney Alina Habba says Trump's lawyers will appeal "the flawed decision" to dismiss his counterclaim. Carroll is also pursuing her own defamation suit against Trump. Her lawyer, Robbie Kaplan, says Carroll is pleased with the ruling and looking ahead to a trial scheduled in January in her defamation suit, which concerns a series of remarks that Trump has made in denying her sexual assault allegation. Carroll accuses Trump of trapping her in a luxury department store dressing room in 1996, where the alleged incident occurred. Trump denies any of it happened, and even that they ran into each other at the store. He has accused her of inventing "a fraudulent and false story" to sell a memoir.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Judge dismisses Donald Trump's defamation suit against E. Jean Carroll, who he was found to have sexually abused

props.alt: Donald Trump in a suit and tie holding an umbrella in the rain next to a car

children.content: (AP: Alex Brandon)
A federal judge in the US has tossed out former president Donald Trump's countersuit against writer E. Jean Carroll, who won a $US5 million ($7.6 million) sex abuse lawsuit against him in May.
The judge ruled that Trump can't claim Carroll defamed him by continuing to say she was not only sexually abused but raped.
Trump attorney Alina Habba says Trump's lawyers will appeal "the flawed decision" to dismiss his counterclaim.
Carroll is also pursuing her own defamation suit against Trump.

Her lawyer, Robbie Kaplan, says Carroll is pleased with the ruling and looking ahead to a trial scheduled in January in her defamation suit, which concerns a series of remarks that Trump has made in denying her sexual assault allegation.
Carroll accuses Trump of trapping her in a luxury department store dressing room in 1996
, where the alleged incident occurred.
Trump denies any of it happened, and even that they ran into each other at the store. He has accused her of inventing "a fraudulent and false story" to sell a memoir.
